moves.4... O-O: Adorjan gambit (E32) of the classical Nimzo-Indian defense.
?  Pa4 thrown to the dogs.  It was safe back on a3 where it was invisible to black's white bishop.
Black has a rook and knight eying that pawn, while white has it covered by the bishop only.
moves.34... Nxe5 35. Ne4 Bc2 36. Nf6+ Rxf6: ?  I'm not sure what was wrong with Kh8.  PxR, BxR, BxN or RxB, I guess black presses an advantage.
moves.37. Bxe5 Rf5 38. Rbe1 Rxg5+ 39. Kh1 Rd1: ?  R and B for a rook?  Oh, right, RxBe5 makes it a nice bloody exchange, ending with black up two pawns of increasing value.
moves.40. Rexd1 Bxd1 41. Rxd1 Rxe5 42. Rc1 c5: Kf8 might have saved the c pawn instead.
???  White must now trade the rook for black's pawn, with Ph4+.
